member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.AssemblyData`1.BindAssemblyReferences(Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.AssemblyData{`0}[])
member.summary: Resolve assembly references against assemblies described by provided AssemblyData objects. In other words, match assembly identities returned by AssemblyReferences property against assemblies described by provided AssemblyData objects.
member.param: An array of AssemblyData objects to match against.
member.returns:
An array of indexes, each element (result[i]) is an index of the assembly the corresponding reference (AssemblyReferences[i]) is bound to: Index >= 0 when reference is bound to an assembly with index (Index) Index = -1 When reference cannot be resolved
The array must have the same size as the one returned by AssemblyReferences.
member.remarks: TODO: Perhaps need some way to get errors for each unresolved reference.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.AssemblyData`1.AssemblyName
member.summary: Identity of the assembly. Implementers of this property may return cached AssemblyName instance. Consumers MUST NOT mutate the AssemblyName instance.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.AssemblyData`1.AssemblyReferences
member.summary: Identity of assemblies referenced by this assembly. References should always be returned in the same order. Implementers of this property may return cached instance of the array and/or cached AssemblyName instances as its elements. Consumers MUST NOT modify the array and MUST NOT mutate the AssemblyName instances.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.AssemblyData`1.AvailableSymbols
member.summary: The sequence of AssemblySymbols the Binder can choose from.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.Binder`1
member.summary:
The purpose of this class is, for the given set of AssemblyData objects, do the following: 1) Resolve references from each assembly against other assemblies in the set. 2) Choose suitable AssemblySymbol instance for each AssemblyData object.
The only entry point for consumers is the Bind method.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.Binder`1.Bind(`0,Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.AssemblyData{`0}[])
member.summary: For the given set of AssemblyData objects, do the following: 1) Resolve references from each assembly against other assemblies in the set. 2) Choose suitable AssemblySymbol instance for each AssemblyData object.
member.param:
An AssemblySymbol instance for the assembly we are building.
If non-null reference is provided, the first element (index==0) of the assemblies array should describe this assembly and its AvailableSymbols property should return sequence, which contains exactly one item and that item is this instance. One can think about the rest of the items in assemblies array as assembly references given to the compiler to build executable for the assemblyBeingBuilt.
The set of AssemblyData objects describing assemblies, for which this method should resolve references and find suitable AssemblySymbols. This array is not modified by the method.
member.returns:
An array of Binding structures describing the result. It has the same amount of items as the input assemblies array, Binding structure for each input AssemblyData object resides at the same position.
Each Binding structure contains the following data:
- Suitable AssemblySymbol instance for the corresponding assembly, null reference if none is available/found.
- Result of resolving assembly references of the corresponding assembly against provided set of assemblies. Essentially, this is an array returned by AssemblyData.BindAssemblyReferences method. Each element (ReferenceBinding[i]) is an index of the AssemblyData object in the input assemblies array, which describes the assembly the corresponding reference (AssemblyReferences[i]) is bound to: Index >= 0 when reference is bound to an assembly with index (Index) Index = -1 When reference cannot be resolved

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.Binder`1.InternalsMayBeVisibleToAssemblyBeingCompiled(System.String,Roslyn.Compilers.MetadataReader.Assembly)
member.summary: Determines if it is possible that gives internals access to assembly . It does not make a conclusive determination of visibility because the compilation's strong name key is not supplied.

members.member:
Return AssemblySymbols referenced by the input AssemblySymbol. The AssemblySymbols must correspond to the AssemblyNames returned by AssemblyData.AssemblyReferences property. If reference is not resolved, null reference should be returned in the corresponding item.
The target AssemblySymbol instance.
An array of AssemblySymbols referenced by the input AssemblySymbol. Implementers may return cached array, Binder does not mutate it.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason
member.summary: Indicates the reasons why a candidate (or set of candidate) symbols were not considered correct in SemanticInfo. Higher values take precedence over lower values, so if, for example, there a symbol with a given name that was inaccessible, and other with the wrong arity, only the inaccessible one would be reported in the SemanticInfo.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.None
member.summary: No CandidateSymbols.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.NotATypeOrNamespace
member.summary: Only a type or namespace was valid in the given location, but the candidate symbols was of the wrong kind.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.WrongArity
member.summary: The candidate symbol takes a different number of type parameters that was required.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.Inaccessible
member.summary: The candidate symbol had an accessibility modifier (private, protected, ...) that made it inaccessible.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.NotReferencable
member.summary: The candidate symbol existed, but was not allowed to be referenced. For example, the "get_XXX" method used to implement a property named "XXX" may not be directly referenced. Similarly, the type "System.Void" can not be directly referenced.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.NotAValue
member.summary: The candidate symbol was in a place where a value was required, but was not a value (e.g., was a a type or namespace).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.NotAVariable
member.summary: The candidate symbol was in a place where a variable (or sometimes, a property) was required, but was not allowed there because it isn't a symbol that can be assigned to. For example, the left hand side of an assignment, or a ref or out parameter.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.NotInvocable
member.summary: The candidate symbol was used in a way that an invocable member (method, or variable of delegate type) was required, but the candidate symbol was not invocable.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.StaticInstanceMismatch
member.summary: The candidate symbol must be an instance variable, but was used as static, or the reverse. Also occurs if "this" is used in a context (static method or field initializer) where "this" is not available.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.OverloadResolutionFailure
member.summary: Overload resolution did not chose a method. The candidate symbols are the methods there were considered during overload resolution (which may or may not be applicable methods).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.CandidateReason.Ambiguous
member.summary: Multiple ambiguous symbols were available with the same name. This can occur if "using" statements bring multiple namespaces into scope, and the same type is available in multiple. This can also occur if multiple properties of the same name are available in a multiple interface inheritance situation.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo
member.summary: Summarizes the semantic information about a syntax node. Includes the symbol(s), the type, and any errors resulting from binding.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.Type
member.summary: The type of the expression represented by the syntax node. For expressions that do not have a type, null is returned. If the type could not be determined due to an error, than an object derived from ErrorTypeSymbol is returned.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.ConvertedType
member.summary: The type of the expression after it has undergone an implicit conversion. If the type did not undergo an implicit conversion, returns the same as Type.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.Symbol
member.summary: The symbol that was referred to by the syntax node, if any. Returns null if the given expression did not bind successfully to a single symbol. If null is returned, it may still be that case that we have one or more "best guesses" as to what symbol was intended. These best guesses are available via the CandidateSymbols property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.CandidateSymbols
member.summary: If the expression did not successfully resolve to a symbol, but there were one or more symbols that may have been considered but discarded, this property returns those symbols. The reason that the symbols did not successfully resolve to a symbol are available in the CandidateReason property. For example, if the symbol was inaccessible, ambiguous, or used in the wrong context.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.CandidateReason
member.summary: If the expression did not successfully resolve to a symbol, but there were one or more symbols that may have been considered but discarded, this property describes why those symbol or symbols were not considered suitable.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.MemberGroup
member.summary: When getting information for a symbol that resolves to a method group or property group, from which a method is then chosen; the chosen method or property is present in Symbol; all methods in the group that was consulted are placed in this property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.IsCompileTimeConstant
member.summary: Returns true if the expression is a compile-time constant. The value of the constant can be obtained with the ConstantValue property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticInfo.ConstantValue
member.summary: If IsCompileTimeConstant returns true, then returns the constant value of the field or enum member. If IsCompileTimeConstant returns false, then returns null.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.DebuggerUtilities.CallBeforeAcquiringLock
member.summary: The issue here is acquiring a lock in the course of evaluating a property value in the debugger (e.g. in the Locals window). If anything causes that evaluation to bail, it will do so without releasing the lock, making future evaluations impossible (leads to a timeout, among other things). One thing that might cause the evaluation to bail is a call to Debugger.NotifyOfCrossThreadDependency, which causes the debugger to prompt the user for confirmation (little swirling red and blue icon) before evaluating an expression that will involve multiple threads. To prevent this from happening we make the call ourselved *before* acquiring the lock. Then, when the user opts to proceed, the evaluation runs without interruption and succeeds.
member.remarks: TODO: This probably isn't necessary in Dev11 (see Dev11 548767 and/or Dev11 84313).

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.AssemblyManager.MetadataCache
member.summary:
Manages cache of the following information for Portable Executables loaded from files.
For assemblies - a map from file name and timestamp to: 1) A weak reference to the corresponding MetadataReader.Assembly object; 2) A list of weak references to instances of VB/CS AssemblySymbols based on the MetadataReader.Assembly object.
For assemblies - a map from file name and timestamp to a weak reference to the corresponding MetadataReader.Module object

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CodeGen.LocalSlotManager
member.summary:
At this level there are two kinds of local variables -
Locals - have identities by which consuming code refers to them. Typical use is a local variable or a compiler generated temp that can be accessed in multiple operations. Any object can be used as identity. Reference equality is used.
Temps - do not have identity. They are borrowed and returned to the free list. Typical use is a scratch temporary or spilling storage.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.CodeGen.ReflectionEmitter
member.summary: Emits types in a given to a .
member.remarks:
Some types can't be emitted either due to the current Reflection.Emit implementation bugs/architecture or due to limitations of collectible assemblies (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd554932.aspx).
The main problem with Reflection.Emit is that it uses two-phase type creation process. s are defined in the first phase and created (baked) one by one in the second. This isn't compatible with the way how CLR Type Loader loads cyclic type references.
The following rules apply and imply a partial order on the type baking (based upon observation and tests; they are not clearly documented anywhere) : 1) Before a type can be baked its derived type and all interfaces it implements needs to be baked. 2) Before a generic type can be baked the constraints of its generic type parameters need to be baked. 3) Before a type can be baked all types of its fields that are value types need to be baked (reference typed fields don't). 4) If a type is dependent on a generic type instantiation it is also dependent on its generic arguments. 5) If a type is dependent on a type nested in another type the outer type need to be baked first.
If these rule imply an order that is not satisfiable (there is a cycle) the emitter throws .
TODO (tomat): Some of these rules can be circumvented by using AppDomain.TypeLoad event, but it's unclear which exactly (I suspect #4).
Examples of type topologies that can't be emitted today are:
class B{T} where T : A // B depends on A by rule #2 class A : B{A} // A depends on B by rule #1
public class E { public struct N2 { public N3 n1; // E.N2 depends on E.N3 by rule #3 and thus on E by rule #5 } public struct N3 { } N2 n2; // E depends on E.N2 by rule #3 }

member.summary: Establishes a creation dependency of on . The can't be baked before is.

An entry point to resolve and return. This could be an arbitrary method, not just PE entry point.
member.returns: The entry point or null if there is none.
member.exception: Reflection.Emit doesn't support the feature being emitted.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Collections.CachingDictionary`2
member.summary:
The CachingLookup class provides a convenient representation of an ILookup that is based upon a potentially slow lookup, and caches lookup results so that subsequent lookups are fast. Internally a ConcurrentDictionary is used to cache lookup results. The client provides two delegates to perform lookups: One that maps a key to a IEnumerable of values, and one that provides all keys.
The client must provide an IEqualityComparer used for comparing keys, and can select whether to cache failed lookups (keys with no values). Caching failed lookups has the disadvantage that every different failed lookup will consume a small amount of extra memory.
Thread safe.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Collections.CachingDictionary`2.#ctor(System.Func{`0,Roslyn.Compilers.ReadOnlyArray{`1}},System.Func{System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0}},System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{`0},System.Boolean,System.Action{Roslyn.Compilers.ReadOnlyArray{`1}})
member.summary: Create a CachingLookup.
member.param: A function that takes a key, and returns an IEnumerable of values that correspond to that key. If no values correspond, the function may either return null or an empty IEnumerable.
A function that returns an IEnumerable of all keys that have associated values.
A IEqualityComparer used to compare keys.
If true, the results of lookups that have no values associated with them are cached. If false, only the results of successful lookups are cached.
A function that is called once new items are cached.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ICompilation
member.summary: The compilation object is an immutable representation of a single invocation of the compiler. Although immutable, a compilation is also on-demand, and will realize and cache data as necessary. A compilation can produce a new compilation from existing compilation with the application of small deltas. In many cases, it is more efficient than creating a new compilation from scratch, as the new compilation can reuse information from the old compilation.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticModel
member.summary: Allows asking semantic questions about a tree of syntax nodes in a Compilation. Typically, an instance is obtained by a call to GetBinding on a Compilation or ICompilation.

remarks.para: An instance of ISemanticModel caches local symbols and semantic information. Thus, it is much more efficient to use a single instance of ISemanticModel when asking multiple questions about a syntax tree, because information from the first question may be reused. This also means that holding onto an instance of ISemanticModel for a long time may keep a significant amount of memory from being garbage collected.

When an answer is a named symbol that is reachable by traversing from the root of the symbol table, (that is, from an AssemblySymbol of the Compilation), that symbol will be returned (i.e. the returned value will be reference-equal to one reachable from the root of the symbol table). Symbols representing entities without names (e.g. array-of-int) may or may not exhibit reference equality. However, some named symbols (such as local variables) are not reachable from the root. These symbols are visible as answers to semantic questions. When the same SemanticModel object is used, the answers exhibit reference-equality.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticModel.GetSemanticInfo(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxNode,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Gets semantic information, such as type, symbols, and diagnostics, about a syntax node.
member.param: The syntax node to get semantic information for.
A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the semantic info.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticModel.GetDeclarationDiagnostics(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the syntax and declaration errors within the syntax tree associated with this object. Does not get errors involving compiling method bodies or initializers.
member.param: A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the diagnostics.
member.remarks: The declaration errors for a syntax tree are cached. The first time this method is called, all declarations are analyzed for diagnostics. Calling this a second time will return the cached diagnostics.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticModel.GetDiagnostics(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the errors within the syntax tree associated with this object. Includes errors involving compiling method bodies or initializers, in addition to the errors returned by GetDeclarationDiagnostics.
member.param: A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the diagnostics.
member.remarks: Because this method must semantically bind all method bodies and initializers to check for diagnostics, it may take a significant amount of time. Unlike GetDeclarationDiagnostics, diagnostics for method bodies and initializers are not cached, the any semantic information used to obtain the diagnostics is discarded.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticModel.GetDeclaredSymbol(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxNode,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Gets the symbol associated with a declaration syntax node.
member.param: A syntax node that is a declaration. This can be any type derived from MemberDeclarationSyntax, TypeDeclarationSyntax, EnumDeclarationSyntax, NamespaceDeclarationSyntax, ParameterSyntax, TypeParameterSyntax, or the alias part of a UsingDirectiveSyntax
The cancellation token.
member.returns: The symbol declared by the node or null if the node is not a declaration.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISemanticModel.LookupSymbols(System.Int32,Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol,System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonLookupOptions)
member.summary: Gets the available named symbols in the context of the specified location and optional container. Only symbols that are accessible and visible from the given location are returned.
member.param: The character position for determining the enclosing declaration scope and accessibility.
The container to search for symbols within. If null then the enclosing declaration scope around position is used.
The name of the symbol to find. If null is specified then symbols with any names are returned.
The number of generic type parameters the symbol has. If null is specified then symbols with any arity are returned.
Additional options that affect the lookup process.
member.returns: A list of symbols that were found. If no symbols were found, an empty list is returned.
member.remarks: The "position" is used to determine what variables are visible and accessible. Even if "container" is specified, the "position" location is significant for determining which members of "containing" are accessible.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.ObjectPool`1
member.summary:
Generic implementation of object pooling pattern with predefined size limit. The main purpose is that limited quantity of frequently used objects can be kept in the pool for further recycling.
Notes: 1) it is not the goal to keep all returned objects. Pool is not meant for storage. If there is no space in the pool, extra returned objects will be dropped.
2) it is implied that if object was obtained from a pool, the caller will return it back in relatively short time.
Not returning objects to the pool in not critical to the pool's work, but is a bad practice. Rationale: If there is no intent for reusing the object, do not get pool involved - just use "new". ///

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.ObjectPool`1.Allocate
member.summary: Produces an instance.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.ObjectPool`1.Free(`0)
member.summary: Returns objects to the pool.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search in Allocate.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.ReadOnlyArray`1
member.summary:
A wrapper that prevents writing to elements of an underlying array. It is a struct to avoid extra allocation and indirections. Equality is determined by reference equality of the underlying array. Implements a struct enumerator to minimize allocations. For similar reasons, it does not implement IEnumerable, but instead implements a subset of the Linq extensions.
This type is expected to be replaced by a BCL type.

member.summary: A singleton representing an empty array.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.ReadOnlyArray`1.ReadOnlyList
member.summary: IList Wrapper on top of ReadOnlyArray

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.ReadOnlyArrayExtensions.AsReadOnlyWrap``1(``0[])
member.summary: DANGER!!! DANGER!!! This method wraps the array!! No copy is made.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Collections.PooledStringBuilder
T:Roslyn.Compilers.UnionCollection`1
member.summary:
Implements a readonly collection over a set of existing collections. This can be used to prevent having to copy items from one collection over to another (thus bloating space).
Note: this is a *collection*, not a *set*. There is no removal of duplicated elements. This allows us to be able to efficiently do operations like CopyTo, Count, etc. in O(c) time instead of O(n) (where 'c' is the number of collections and 'n' is the number of eleemnts). If you have a few collections with many elements in them, then this is an appropriate collection for you.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Utilities.SyntaxPath
member.summary:
Stores the "path" from the root of a tree to a node, allowing the node to be recovered in a later snapshot of the tree, under certain circumstances.
The implementation stores the child indices to represent the path, so any edit which affects the child indices could render this object unable to recover its node. NOTE: One thing C# IDE has done in the past to do a better job of this is to store the fully qualified name of the member to at least be able to descend into the same member. We could apply the same sort of logic here.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.SyntaxPath.TryResolve(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxNode,Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxNodeOrToken@)
member.summary: Attempts to recover the node at this path in the provided tree. If the node is found then 'true' is returned, otherwise the result is 'false' and 'node' will be null.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SynchronizedBag`1
member.summary:
A _very_ simple implementation of the BCL's ConcurrentBag. In .NET 4.0, there is a bug where objects in the bag are leaked until the thread where they are added exits. Because we use them on ThreadPool based threads (via the TPL), we can't control when the thread exits.
The BCL bug is tracked by http://vstfdevdiv:8080/web/wi.aspx?id=14770, and we should consider removing this type and using the BCL's version once we are on a platform where it is supported.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SynchronizedBag`1.DangerousIsEmpty
member.summary: NOTE: Be careful using this, because another thread could add/remove an item immediately after you call access it, which means it's value could be out of date by the time you act on it. ///

member.name: F:Roslyn.Scripting.CommonSubmissionCompilationFactory.globalAssemblyNamePrefix
member.summary: Unique prefix for generated uncollectible assemblies.
member.remarks:
The full names of uncollectible assemblies generated by this context must be unique, so that we can resolve references among them. Note that CLR can load two different assemblies of the very identity into the same load context.
We are using a certain naming scheme for the generated assemblies (a fixed name prefix followed by a number). If we allowed the compiled code to add references that match this exact pattern it migth happen that the user supplied reference identity conflicts with the identity we use for our generated assemblies and the AppDomain assembly resolve event won't be able to correctly identify the target assembly.
To avoid this problem we use a prefix for assemblies we generate that is unlikely to conflict with user specified references. We also check that no user provided references are allowed to be used in the compiled code and report an error ("reserved assembly name").

member.name: M:Roslyn.Scripting.CommonObjectFormatter.FormatObjectMembersRecursive(System.Collections.Generic.List{Roslyn.Scripting.CommonObjectFormatter.FormattedMember},System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.Object},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerates sorted object members to display.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Scripting.CommonObjectFormatter.FormatWithEmbeddedExpressions(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluate a format string with possible member references enclosed in braces. E.g. "foo = {GetFooString(),nq}, bar = {Bar}".
member.remarks:
Although in theory any expression is allowed to be embedded in the string such behavior is in practice fundamentally broken. The attribute doesn't specify what language (VB, C#, F#, etc.) to use to parse these expressions. Even if it did all languages would need to be able to evaluate each other language's expressions, which is not viable and the Expression Evaluator doesn't work that way today. Instead it evaluates the embedded expressions in the language of the current method frame. When consuming VB objects from C#, for example, the evaluation migth fail due to language mismatch (evaluating VB expression using C# parser).
Therefore we limit the expressions to a simple language independent syntax: {clr-member-name} '(' ')' ',nq', where parentheses and ,nq suffix (no-quotes) are optional and the name is an arbitrary CLR field, property, or method name. We then resolve the member by name using case-sensitive lookup first with fallback to case insensitive and evaluate it. If parentheses are present we only look for methods. Only parameter less members are considered.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Scripting.Session
member.summary: Runtime representation of an interactive session.
member.remarks: Session is not thread-safe, i.e. parallel executions against the same session object might fail. However executing methods defined in a context of a session in parallel is safe as long as the methods themselves are thread-safe. (i.e. accessing data from previous submissions is safe as long as they are readonly or guarded by a user maintained lock).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.QualifiedNameArityFormat

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.ILVisualizationFormat

Constructs a new instance of accepting a variety of optional parameters.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.GlobalNamespaceStyle

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.TypeQualificationStyle
member.summary: Determines how types are qualified (e.g. Nested vs Containing.Nested vs Namespace.Containing.Nested).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.GenericsOptions
member.summary: Determines how generics (on types and methods) should be described (i.e. level of detail).

member.summary: Formatting options that apply to fields, properties, and methods.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.ParameterOptions
member.summary: Formatting options that apply to method and indexer parameters (i.e. level of detail).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.DelegateStyle
member.summary: Determines how delegates are displayed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.ExtensionMethodStyle
member.summary: Determines how extension methods are displayed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.PropertyStyle
member.summary: Determines how properties are displayed. "Prop" vs "Prop { get; set; }" ("Prop" vs. "ReadOnly Prop" in VB)

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.LocalStyle
member.summary: Determines how local variables are displayed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.KindOptions
member.summary: Formatting options that apply to types.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.MiscellaneousOptions
member.summary: Miscellaneous formatting options.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayFormat.CompilerInternalOptions
member.summary: Flags that can only be set within the compiler.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions
member.summary: Specifies the options for how generics are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.None
member.summary: Omit generics entirely.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.IncludeTypeParameters
member.summary: Type parameters. e.g. "Foo<T>" ("Foo(of T)" in VB).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.IncludeTypeConstraints
member.summary: Type parameter constraints. e.g. "where T : new()" ("of T as New" in VB).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.IncludeVariance
member.summary: Use out/in before type parameter if it has one. e.g. "Foo<out T>" ("Foo Of Out T" in VB).

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle
member.summary: Specifies the options for how to display the global namespace in the description of a symbol.
member.remarks: Any of these styles may be overridden by SymbolDisplayTypeQualificationStyle.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle.Omitted
member.summary: Omit the global namespace.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle.OmittedAsContaining
member.summary: Omit the global namespace if it is being displayed as a containing symbol (i.e. not on its own).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle.Included
member.summary: Include the global namespace.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayLocalStyle
member.summary: Specifies the options for how locals are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayLocalStyle.NameOnly
member.summary: Only show the name of the local (e.g. "x").

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayLocalStyle.NameAndType
member.summary: Show the name and the type of the local. e.g. "int x" ("dim x as Integer" in VB).

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions
member.summary: Specifies the options for how members are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.None
member.summary: Display only the name of the member.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeType
member.summary: Include the (return) type of the method/field/property.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeModifiers
member.summary: Include modifiers. e.g. "static readonly" ("Shared ReadOnly" in VB).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeAccessibility
member.summary: Include accessibility. e.g. "public" ("Public" in VB).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeExplicitInterface
member.summary: Indicate properties and methods that explicitly implement interfaces. e.g. "IFoo.Bar { get; }". This has no effect in VB.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeParameters
member.summary: Include method/indexer parameters. (See ParameterFlags for fine-grained settings.)

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeContainingType
member.summary: Include the name of the containing type.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions
member.summary: Specifies the miscellaneous options for how elements are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.UseSpecialTypes
member.summary: Use keywords for predefined types. "int?" instead of "System.Nullable<System.Int32>" ("Integer?" instead of "Nullable(of Integer)" in VB)

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.EscapeKeywordIdentifiers
member.summary: "@true" instead of "true". ("[True]" instead of "True" in VB)

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.UseAsterisksInMultiDimensionalArrays
member.summary: "int[][*,*]" instead of "int[][,]". ("Integer()(*,*)" in VB)

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.UseErrorTypeSymbolName
member.summary: Displays "<Error>" for unknown type names

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.None
member.summary: If MemberFlags.IncludeParameters is set, but this value is used, then only the parentheses will be shown (e.g. M()).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeExtensionThis
member.summary: Include the 'this' keyword before the first parameter of an extension method. This has no effect in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeParamsRefOut
member.summary: Include the params/ref/out keyword ("ByRef/ByVal" in Visual Basic) before params/ref/out parameters (no effect if the type is not included).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeType
member.summary: Include the parameter type.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeName
member.summary: Include the parameter name.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeDefaultValue
member.summary: Include the parameter default value (no effect if the name is not included).

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeOptionalBrackets
member.summary: Include square brackets around optional parameters.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayPropertyStyle

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.SymbolDisplayPropertyStyle.GetSet

member.summary: Gets the for the immediately containing symbol.

member.summary: Gets the for the containing assembly. Returns null if the symbol is shared across multiple assemblies.

member.summary: Gets the for the nearest enclosing namespace. Returns null if the symbol isn't contained in a namespace.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is the original definition. Returns false if the symbol is derived from another symbol, by type substitution for instance.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsStatic
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is static.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsVirtual
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is virtual.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsOverride
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is an override of a base class symbol.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsAbstract
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is abstract.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsSealed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is sealed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsObsolete
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is marked as obsolete.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsExtern
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol is defined externally.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.IsSynthesized
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the symbol was generated by the compiler rather than declared explicitly.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.Locations
member.summary: Gets the locations where the symbol was originally defined, either in source or metadata. Some symbols (for example, partial classes) may be defined in more than one location.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.DeclaredAccessibility
member.summary: Gets a indicating the declared accessibility for the symbol. Returns NotApplicable if no accessibility is declared.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ISymbol.OriginalDefinition
member.summary: Gets the for the original definition of the symbol. If this symbol is derived from another symbol, by type substitution for instance, this gets the original symbol, as it was defined in source or metadata.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAliasSymbol.Target
member.summary: Gets the for the namespace or type referenced by the alias.

member.summary: Represents an array.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol
member.summary: Represents either a namespace or a type.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol.GetMembers(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol.
member.returns: A ReadOnlyArray containing all the members of this symbol. If this symbol has no members, returns an empty ReadOnlyArray. Never returns Null.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol.GetMembers(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol that have a particular name.
member.returns: A ReadOnlyArray containing all the members of this symbol with the given name. If there are no members with this name, returns an empty ReadOnlyArray. Never returns Null.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol.GetTypeMembers(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol that are types.
member.returns: An IEnumerable containing all the types that are members of this symbol. If this symbol has no type members, returns an empty IEnumerable. Never returns Nothing.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol.GetTypeMembers(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol that are types that have a particular name, of any arity.
member.returns: A ReadOnlyArray containing all the types that are members of this symbol with the given name. If this symbol has no type members with this name, returns an empty ReadOnlyArray. Never returns Null.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.TypeKind
member.summary: An enumerated value that identifies whether this type is an array, pointer, enum, and so on.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.BaseType
member.summary: The declared base type of this type, or null. The object type, interface types, and pointer types do not have a base type. The base type of a type parameter is its effective base class.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.Interfaces
member.summary: Gets the set of interfaces that this type directly implements. This set does not include interfaces that are base interfaces of directly implemented interfaces. This does include the interfaces declared as constraints on type parameters.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.AllInterfaces
member.summary: The list of all interfaces of which this type is a declared subtype, excluding this type itself. This includes all declared base interfaces, all declared base interfaces of base types, and all declared base interfaces of those results (recursively). This also is the effective interface set of a type parameter. Each result appears exactly once in the list. This list is topologically sorted by the inheritance relationship: if interface type A extends interface type B, then A precedes B in the list. This is not quite the same as "all interfaces of which this type is a proper subtype" because it does not take into account variance: AllInterfaces for IEnumerable<string> will not include IEnumerble<object>

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.IsReferenceType
member.summary: True if this type is known to be a reference type. It is never the case that IsReferenceType and IsValueType both return true. However, for an unconstrained type parameter, IsReferenceType and IsValueType will both return false.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.IsValueType
member.summary: True if this type is known to be a value type. It is never the case that IsReferenceType and IsValueType both return true. However, for an unconstrained type parameter, IsReferenceType and IsValueType will both return false.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.OriginalDefinition
member.summary: The original definition of this symbol. If this symbol is constructed from another symbol by type substitution then OriginalDefinition gets the original symbol as it was defined in source or metadata.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ITypeSymbol.SpecialType
member.summary: An enumerated value that identifies certain 'special' types such as System.Object. Returns SpecialType.None if the type is not special.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IArrayTypeSymbol.Rank
member.summary: Gets the number of dimensions of this array. A regular single-dimensional array has rank 1, a two-dimensional array has rank 2, etc.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IArrayTypeSymbol.ElementType
member.summary: Gets the type of the elements stored in the array.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IArrayTypeSymbol.CustomModifiers
member.summary: Gets the list of custom modifiers associated with the array. Returns an empty list if there are no custom modifiers.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol
member.summary: Represents a .NET assembly, consisting of one or more modules.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this assembly gives access to internal symbols

member.summary: Gets the symbol for the pre-defined type from core library associated with this assembly.
member.returns: The symbol for the pre-defined type or null if the type is not defined in the core library.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.GetTypeByMetadataName(System.String)

member.param: Type name.
member.returns: Symbol for the type or null if type cannot be found or is ambiguous.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.IsInteractive
member.summary: True if the assembly contains interactive code.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.AssemblyName
member.summary: Gets the name of this assembly.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.GlobalNamespace
member.summary: Gets the merged root namespace that contains all namespaces and types defined in the modules of this assembly. If there is just one module in this assembly, this property just returns the GlobalNamespace of that module.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.Modules
member.summary: Gets the modules in this assembly. (There must be at least one.) The first one is the main module that holds the assembly manifest.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.TypeNames
member.summary: Gets the set of type identifiers from this assembly.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IAssemblySymbol.NamespaceNames
member.summary: Gets the set of namespace names from this assembly.

member.summary: This is a temporary hack that allows us to get all the names of the assembly that this assembly has declared InternalsVisibleTo. This should go away once we actually support attributes properly.

member.summary: Returns true if this field was declared as "readonly".

member.summary: Returns true if this field was declared as "volatile".

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IFieldSymbol.ConstantValue
member.summary: Gets the constant value of this field

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IFieldSymbol.CustomModifiers

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILabelSymbol

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILocalSymbol
member.summary: Represents a local variable in method body

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILocalSymbol.Type
member.summary: Gets the type of this local variable.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILocalSymbol.ContainingMethod
member.summary: Gets the immediately containing of this .

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILocalSymbol.IsConst
member.summary: Returns true if this local variable was declared as "const" (i.e. is a constant declaration). Also returns true for an enum member.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILocalSymbol.HasConstantValue
member.summary: Returns false if the local variable wasn't declared as "const", or constant value was omitted or errorneous. True otherwise.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.ILocalSymbol.ConstantValue

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol
member.summary: Represents a method or method-like symbol (including constructor, destructor, operator, or property/event accessor).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.MethodKind
member.summary: Gets what kind of method this is. There are several different kinds of things in the C# language that are represented as methods. This property allow distinguishing those things without having to decode the name of the method.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.Arity
member.summary: Returns the arity of this method, or the number of type parameters it takes. A non-generic method has zero arity.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.IsGenericMethod
member.summary: Returns whether this method is generic; i.e., does it have any type parameters?

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.IsExtensionMethod
member.summary: Returns true if this method is an extension method.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.IsVarArgs
member.summary:
Returns whether this method is using CLI VARARG calling convention. This is used for C-style variable argument lists. This is used extremely rarely in C# code and is represented using the undocumented __arglist keyword.
Note that methods with params on the last parameter are indicated with the IsParams property on ParameterSymbol, and are not represented with this property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.HidesBaseMethodByName
member.summary: Returns true if this method hides base methods by name. This cannot be specified directly in the C# language, but can be true for methods defined in other languages imported from metadata. The equivalent of the "hidebyname" flag in metadata.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.ReturnsVoid
member.summary: Returns true if this method has no return type; i.e., returns "void".

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.ReturnType
member.summary: Gets the return type of the method.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.TypeArguments
member.summary: Returns the type arguments that have been substituted for the type parameters. If nothing has been substituted for a given type parameter, then the type parameter itself is consider the type argument.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.TypeParameters
member.summary: Get the type parameters on this method. If the method has not generic, returns an empty list.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.Parameters
member.summary: Gets the parameters of this method. If this method has no parameters, returns an empty list.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.ConstructedFrom
member.summary: Returns the method symbol that this method was constructed from. The resulting method symbol has the same containing type (if any), but has type arguments that are the same as the type parameters (although its containing type might not).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.OriginalDefinition
member.summary: Get the original definition of this symbol. If this symbol is derived from another symbol by (say) type substitution, this gets the original symbol, as it was defined in source or metadata.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.OverriddenMethod
member.summary: If this method overrides another method (because it both had the override modifier on it, and there correctly was a method to override, returns the overridden method.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.ExplicitInterfaceImplementations
member.summary: Returns interface methods explicitly implemented by this method.
member.remarks: Methods imported from metadata can explicitly implement more than one method, that is why return type is ReadOnlyArray.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.ReturnTypeCustomModifiers
member.summary: Returns the list of custom modifiers, if any, associated with the returned value.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.ReturnTypeAttributes
member.summary: Returns the list of custom attributes, if any, associated with the returned value.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IMethodSymbol.AssociatedPropertyOrEvent
member.summary: If this method has MethodKind of MethodKind.PropertyGet or MethodKind.PropertySet, returns the property that this method is the getter or setter for. If this method has MethodKind of MethodKind.EventAdd or MethodKind.EventRemove, returns the event that this method is the adder or remover for.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IModuleSymbol
member.summary: Represents a module within an assembly. Every assembly contains one or more modules.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IModuleSymbol.GetModuleNamespace(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceSymbol)
member.summary: Given a namespace symbol, returns the corresponding module specific namespace symbol

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IModuleSymbol.GlobalNamespace
member.summary: Returns a NamespaceSymbol representing the global (root) namespace, with module extent, that can be used to browse all of the symbols defined in this module.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol
member.summary: Represents a type other than an array, a pointer, a type parameter.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.Arity
member.summary: Returns the arity of this type, or the number of type parameters it takes. A non-generic type has zero arity.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.IsGenericType
member.summary: True if this type or some containing type has type parameters.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.IsScriptClass
member.summary: Returns true if the type is a Script class. It might be an interactive submission class or a Script class in a csx file.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.IsImplicitClass
member.summary: Returns true if the type is the implicit class that holds onto invalid global members (like methods or statements in a non script file).

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.MemberNames
member.summary: Returns collection of names of members declared within this type.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.TypeParameters
member.summary: Returns the type parameters that this type has. If this is a non-generic type, returns an empty ReadOnlyArray.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.TypeArguments
member.summary: Returns the type arguments that have been substituted for the type parameters. If nothing has been substituted for a give type parameters, then the type parameter itself is consider the type argument.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.OriginalDefinition
member.summary: Get the original definition of this type symbol. If this symbol is derived from another symbol by (say) type substitution, this gets the original symbol, as it was defined in source or metadata.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.DelegateInvokeMethod
member.summary: For delegate types, gets the delegate's invoke method. Returns null on all other kinds of types. Note that is is possible to have an ill-formed delegate type imported from metadata which does not have an Invoke method. Such a type will be classified as a delegate but its DelegateInvokeMethod would be null.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.EnumUnderlyingType
member.summary: For enum types, gets the underlying type. Returns null on all other kinds of types.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol.ConstructedFrom
member.summary: Returns the type symbol that this type was constructed from. This type symbol has the same containing type (if any), but has type arguments that are the same as the type parameters (although its containing type might not).

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbolExtensions
member.summary: Defines extension methods for the INamedTypeSymbol interface.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbolExtensions.GetInstanceConstructors(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol)
member.summary: Returns the instance constructors.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbolExtensions.GetStaticConstructors(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol)
member.summary: Returns static constructors.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbolExtensions.GetConstructors(Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamedTypeSymbol)
member.summary: Get the constructors.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceSymbol
member.summary: Represents a namespace.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceSymbol.GetMembers(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceSymbol.GetMembers(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol that have a particular name.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceSymbol.GetNamespaceMembers(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the members of this symbol that are namespaces.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.INamespaceSymbol.IsGlobalNamespace
member.summary: Returns whether this namespace is the unnamed, global namespace that is at the root of all namespaces.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol
member.summary: Represents a parameter of a method or property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.RefKind
member.summary: Whether the parameter passed by value or by reference.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.IsParams
member.summary: Returns true if the parameter was declared as a parameter array.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.IsOptional
member.summary: Returns true if the parameter is optional.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.IsThis
member.summary: Returns true if the parameter is the hidden 'this' ('Me' in Visual Basic) parameter.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.Type
member.summary: Gets the type of the parameter.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.CustomModifiers
member.summary: The list of custom modifiers, if any, associated with the parameter.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.Ordinal
member.summary: Gets the ordinal position of the parameter. The first parameter has ordinal zero. The 'this' parameter ('Me' in Visual Basic) has ordinal -1.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.HasDefaultValue
member.summary: Returns true if the parameter specifies a default value to be passed when no value is provided as an argument to a call. The default value can be obtained with the DefaultValue property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IParameterSymbol.DefaultValue
member.summary: Returns the default value of the parameter. If HasDefaultValue returns false then DefaultValue throws an InvalidOperationException.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPointerTypeSymbol
member.summary: Represents a pointer type such as "int *". Pointer types are used only in unsafe code.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPointerTypeSymbol.PointedAtType
member.summary: Gets the type of the storage location that an instance of the pointer type points to.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPointerTypeSymbol.CustomModifiers
member.summary: The list of custom modifiers, if any, associated with the pointer type. (Some managed languages may represent special information about the pointer type as a custom modifier on either the pointer type or the element type, or both.)

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol
member.summary: Represents a property or indexer.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.IsIndexer
member.summary: Returns whether the property is really an indexer.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.IsReadOnly
member.summary: True if this is a read-only property; that is, a property with no set accessor.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.IsWriteOnly
member.summary: True if this is a write-only property; that is, a property with no get accessor.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.Type
member.summary: The type of the property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.Parameters
member.summary: The parameters of this property. If this property has no parameters, returns an empty list. Parameters are only present on indexers, or on some properties imported from a COM interface.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.GetMethod
member.summary: The 'get' accessor of the property, or null if the property is write-only.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.SetMethod
member.summary: The 'set' accessor of the property, or null if the property is read-only.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.OriginalDefinition
member.summary: The original definition of the property. If the property is constructed from another symbol by type substitution, OriginalDefinition gets the original symbol, as it was defined in source or metadata.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.OverriddenProperty
member.summary: Returns the overridden property, or null.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.ExplicitInterfaceImplementations
member.summary: Returns interface properties explicitly implemented by this property.
member.remarks: Properties imported from metadata can explicitly implement more than one property.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.IPropertySymbol.TypeCustomModifiers
member.summary: The list of custom modifiers, if any, associated with the type of the property.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxNode.CopyAnnotations``1(``0)
member.summary:
Finds any annotations that are on node "from", and then attaches them to node "to", returning a new node with the annotations attached.
If no annotations are copied, just returns "to".
It can also be used manually to preserve annotations in a more complex tree modification, even if the type of a node changes.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.DiagnosticBag
member.summary:
Represents a thread-safe, mutable bag of diagnostics. You can add diagnostics to the bag, and also get all the diagnostics out of the bag (the bag implements IEnumerable<Diagnostics>. Once added, diagnostics cannot be removed, and no ordering is guaranteed.
The bag can also be sealed, after which attempts to add additional errors will throw an exception. This is a useful to present errors from being incorrectly added to a bag too late.
member.remarks: Thread Safe. It is optimized to be efficient when containing zero errors.

member.summary: Please use DiagnosticBag.GetInstance instead.

member.summary: Add multiple diagnostics to the bag.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.CommonSyntaxTree.FileName
member.summary: The name of the source document file.
member.remarks:
If this syntax tree is not associated with a file, this FileName can (and often will) be the empty string.
Clients must not assume that a file exists on disk with the given name, even if a non-empty string is returned. Clients must also not assume that the values of this property are unique within a Compilation.
The FileName is used in two important ways: When debug information is emitted, this name is embedded in the debug information. When the GetLineSpan function on the SyntaxTree is called, it is used as the file name in the returned FileLinePositionSpan.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Common.LineDirectiveMap
member.summary: The LineDirectiveMap is created to enable translating positions, using the #line directives in a file. The basic implementation creates an ordered array of line mapping entries, one for each #line directive in the file (plus one at the beginning). If the file has no directives, then the array has just one element in in. To map line numbers, a binary search of the mapping entries is done and nearest line mapping is applied.

member.name: F:Roslyn.Compilers.MetadataReader.Module.lazyTypeDefToTypeIdentifierMap
member.summary: For each TypeDef that has 1 in m_lazyNoPiaLocalTypeCheckBitMap, this map stores corresponding TypeIdentifier row id combined with index of target constructor signature ((rowid << 8) | index)

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.MetadataReader.Module.ComputeSHA1
member.summary: Compute SHA1 hash of the module.

members.member:
The function groups types defined in the module by their fully-qualified namespace name. The grouping is case-sensitive, however, if TypeDefs in metadata are not reusing the same StringId for the same namespace name, there could be multiple groups for each namespace name. Though this situation is not very likely, consumers of the result should be prepared to handle it.
The sequence is sorted by name by using provided comparer. Therefore, if there are multiple groups for a namespace name, the groups are going to be adjacent to each other.
Empty string is used as namespace name for types in the Global namespace. Therefore, all types in the Global namespace, if any, will be in the several IGroupings at the very beginning of the sequence.
Comparer to sort the groups.
TypeDef row ids grouped by fully-qualified namespace name.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Compilers.ModuleFileReference.Kind
member.summary: Gets the kind of reference this is. This is useful for avoiding expensive type tests.
Calculates information about types and namespaces immediately contained within a namespace.
member.param: Length of the fully-qualified name of this namespace.

The sequence of groups of TypeDef row ids for types contained within the namespace, recursively including those from nested namespaces. The row ids must be grouped by the fully-qualified namespace name in case-sensitive manner. Key of each IGrouping is a fully-qualified namespace name, which starts with the name of this namespace. There could be multiple groups for each fully-qualified namespace name.
The groups must be sorted by the keys in a manner consistent with comparer passed in as nameComparer. Therefore, all types immediately contained within THIS namespace, if any, must be in several IGrouping at the very beginning of the sequence.
Equality comparer to compare namespace names.
Output parameter, never null: A sequence of groups of TypeDef row ids for types immediately contained within this namespace.

Output parameter, never null: A sequence with information about namespaces immediately contained within this namespace. For each pair: Key - contains simple name of a child namespace. Value contains a sequence similar to the one passed to this function, but calculated for the child namespace.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Internal.MetadataHelpers.ExtractSimpleNameOfChildNamespace(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Extract a simple name of a top level child namespace from potentially qualified namespace name.
member.param: Parent namespace name length plus the dot.
Fully qualified namespace name.
member.returns: Simple name of a top level child namespace, the left-most name following parent namespace name in the fully qualified name.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Compilers.Internal.MetadataHelpers.SerializedTypeDecoder
member.summary: Decodes a serialized type name in its canonical form. The canonical name is its full type name, followed optionally by the assembly where it is defined, its version, culture and public key token. If the assembly name is omitted, the type name is in the current assembly otherwise it is in the referenced assembly. The full type name is the fully qualified metadata type name.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Compilers.Internal.MetadataHelpers.SerializedTypeDecoder.DecodeTypeName(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Decodes a type name. A type name is a string which is terminated by the end of the string or one of the delimiters '+', ',', '[', ']', '`' or '!' ('!' is obsolete). '+' separates nested classes. '[' and ']' enclosed generic type arguments. ',' separates types.

member.summary: Decodes a generic name. This is a type name followed optional by a type parameter count

The former routine will call Visit(INamespaceTypeDefinition) rather than Visit(INamespaceTypeReference), etc., in the case where a definition is used as a reference to itself.
